10904Journal of Inorganic and Organometallic Polymers and MaterialsJ Inorg Organomet Polym1574-14431574-1451Kluwer Academic Publishers-Plenum PublishersNew Yorks10904-006-9055-6905510.1007/s10904-006-9055-6ArticleSelf-Recognition of 3D Porous Frameworks: Fourfold Diamondoid or Threefold Cuboidal Interpenetrating Nets Formed by Varying Pillar MotifsHsuLiang-Ping12WuJing-Yun1LuKuang-Lieh1cgrid.28665.3f0000000122871366Institute of ChemistryAcademia Sinica115TaipeiTaiwangrid.37589.300000000405323167Department of ChemistryNational Central University320ChungliTaiwanlu@chem.sinica.edu.tw1711200632007171Special Issue Dedicated to Ian Manners259265288200617112006© Springer Science+Business Media, LLC 20062006

Compound [Ni(2,6-ndc)(bpe)(H2O)]n (1) was prepared by the hydrothermal reaction of 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (2,6-H2ndc) and trans-1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethylene (bpe) with Ni(NO3)2·6H2O under alkaline (NaOH) conditions. Treatment of 2,6-H2ndc, 4,4′-bipyridine (4,4′-bpy) with M(NO3)2·6H2O (M = Ni or Co) under similar conditions afforded compounds [Ni2(2,6-ndc)2(4,4′-bpy)]n (2) and [Co2(2,6-ndc)2(4,4′-bpy)]n (3), respectively. A single-crystal X-ray diffraction study revealed that compound 1 adopts a 3D fourfold interpenetrating diamondoid network stabilized by inter-net OH···O hydrogen bonds. The anionic 2,6-ndc ligand presents two different bonding characteristics, bis(monodentate) and bis(chelating bidentate) modes. A solid-state structural analysis revealed that compounds 2 and 3 are isomorphous and isostructural. Both present a 3D threefold interpenetrating cuboidal framework, consisting of a 2D (4,4)-net of interconnected [M2(O2C)4] (M = Ni, Co) paddle-wheel dinuclear units, and pillared by 4,4′-bpy ligands. The degree of interpenetration of these compounds could be adjusted successfully by varying only the organic pillar motifs.

The fabrication of metal-directed inorganic–organic hybrid open frameworks through crystal engineering is of great interest partly because of their potential applications as functional materials [1–5]. Among the several types of net-assembled polymeric frameworks reported so far, ordered, periodic entanglement interpenetrating nets are often encountered. In comparison with encapsulation to “hetero-recognition”, the decorated interpenetrating networks may be apt to have “self-recognition” [6] characteristics, to avoid the formation of large open channels or cavities, thus presenting a unique class of model compounds for studies dealing with the modification of their robustness, degree of interpenetration, and porosity [5, 7–28]. Interpenetration is thought to have a negative impact on the size and accessibility of pores in microporous materials. Although it is most likely strongly related to the length of the spacer ligands, factors that control the degree of interpenetration during the self-assembly process remain largely unknown and/or unproven [9, 10]. We recently have successfully demonstrated a feasible way for obtaining accessible free volume and permanent porosity in a thermally stable, fourfold interpenetrating diamondoid net, Cd(imidazole-4-acrylate)2, by employing strong net-to-net hydrogen bonding interactions [15]. Herein we report on controlling the diversity of the structural topologies in porous polymeric networks. The self-recognition of 3D porous frameworks, leading to the formation of either a fourfold interpenetrating diamondoid net or a threefold interpenetrating cuboidal net, can be tuned by varying only the organic pillar spacer under hydrothermal conditions.

ExperimentalGeneral Remarks

All reagents were purchased from commercial sources and were used as received without further purification. Elemental analyses were conducted on a Perkin–Elmer 2400 CHN elemental analyzer. Thermogravimetric (TG) analyses were performed under flowing nitrogen on a Perkin–Elmer TGA-7 analyzer at a heating rate of 3 °C/min for all measurements.

Synthesis of [Ni(2,6-ndc)(bpe)(H<sub>2</sub>O)]<sub><italic>n</italic></sub>(<bold>1</bold>)

A mixture of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (0.30 mmol), 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (2,6-H2ndc, 0.10 mmol), trans-1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethylene (bpe, 0.10 mmol), and NaOH (0.65 M, 0.3 mL) in an aqueous solution (3 mL) was conducted in an acid digestion bomb, which was heated at 160 °C for 72 h, and then slowly cooled to room temperature at a rate 3.3 °C per hour. Greenish crystals of [Ni(2,6-ndc)(bpe)(H2O)]n(1) were obtained and collected in 28% yield by filtration and washed with ethanol, and then dried at room temperature. Elemental analysis for NiC24H18N2O5, Calcd. (%): C: 60.93, H: 3.83, N: 5.92; Found: C: 61.30, H: 3.65, N: 5.40.

Synthesis of [Ni<sub>2</sub>(2,6-ndc)<sub>2</sub>(4,4′-bpy)]<sub><italic>n</italic></sub>(<bold>2</bold>)

Green crystals of 2 were obtained by adopting the same conditions as 1 but using 4,4′-bipyridine 4,4′-bpy instead of trans-1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethylene. Yield: 95%. Elemental analysis for NiC17H10NO4, Calcd. (%): C: 58.18, H: 2.87, N: 3.99; Found: C: 57.96, H: 2.84, N: 3.99.

Synthesis of [Co<sub>2</sub>(2,6-ndc)<sub>2</sub>(4,4′-bpy)]<sub><italic>n</italic></sub>(<bold>3</bold>)

Brown crystals of 3 were obtained by adopting the same procedures as 1, while Co(NO3)2·6H2O and 4,4′-bpy were used instead of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O and trans-1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethylene. Yield: 59%. Elemental analysis for CoC17H10NO4, Calcd. (%): C: 58.14, H: 2.87, N: 3.99; Found: C: 57.95, H: 2.72, N: 4.07.

X-ray Crystallography

Suitable single crystals of 1–3 were selected for indexing and the collection of intensity data. Measurements were performed using graphite-monochromatized Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) on a Nonius Kappa CCD. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares method on F2 using the SHELX-97 [29] program packages. Anisotropical thermal factors were assigned to non-hydrogen atoms. The C–H hydrogen atoms were assigned by geometrical calculation and refined as a riding model while the O–H hydrogen atoms were located from the difference Fourier maps. Basic information pertaining to the crystal parameters and structure refinements for 1–3 are summarized in Table I. CCDC-618016 (1), CCDC-618017 (2), and CCDC-618018 (3) contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge at http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/conts/retrieving.htm [or from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB21EZ, UK; fax: (+44) 1223-336-033; or e-mail: deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk]

Results and Discussion

Hydrothermal reactions of 2,6-H2ndc and bpe with Ni(NO3)2·6H2O under alkaline (NaOH) conditions successfully afforded greenish crystals (Scheme 1), which were characterized as [Ni(2,6-ndc)(bpe)(H2O)]n (1) by elemental analysis and single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies. As shown in Fig. 1, the nickel center in 1 is present in a distorted octahedral geometry of N2O4 donor sets, arising from two distinct bpe ligands in a cis configuration (Ni1–N1 = 2.078(4) Å, Ni1–N2 = 2.082(4) Å, N1–Ni1–N2, 87.95(14)°, Table II), one monodentate and one chelated carboxylate group from two 2,6-ndc ligands (Ni1–O = 2.029(3)–2.168(3) Å), and one water molecule (Ni1–O1 = 2.074(3) Å). Both of the two crystallographically independent 2,6-ndc ligands are bridged to two NiII ions, but their bonding characteristics are different, viz bis(monodentate) and bis(chelating bidentate) modes. The coordinated water molecule (O1) is intramolecularly hydrogen bonded (H···O, 1.82 Å; O···O, 2.58 Å; OH···O, 133°) to the non-coordinated nearby oxygen (O3) of the monodentate carboxylate group of the 2,6-ndc ligand. This hydrogen bonding interaction plays an important role in stabilizing the structure.

Interestingly, the six-coordinated NiII center acts as a pseudo-tetrahedral four-connected node, which connects to four other NiII centers through two anionic 2,6-ndc and two neutral bpe ligands, resulting in the formation of a diamondoid network (Fig. 2). The Ni···Ni separations in the adamantoid cage unit along Ni···2,6-ndc···Ni are 12.88 and 13.59 Å, while, for Ni···bpe···Ni, the values are 13.53 and 13.54 Å. The large void space generated is filled by the appearance of a fourfold diamondoid structure, in which four independent equivalent nets are interpenetrated in the aligned normal type with an equally inter-net space of 7.599 Å, along the a axis (the shortest one) of the unit cell, thus, leading to an overall dense phase. The interpenetrating 3D diamondoid net of 1 is further stabilized through noncovalent inter-net OH···O hydrogen bonds (H···O, 2.10 Å; O···O, 2.76 Å; OH···O5, 125°) between the coordinated water molecule (O1) and one of the chelated carboxylate oxygen (O5) atom of 2,6-ndc ligand in neighboring net. This provides a good case for comparison with a fourfold interpenetrating diamondoid net, Cd(imidazole-4-acrylate)2, which presents spring-like NH···O net-to-net hydrogen-bonding interactions and causes an abnormal type of interpenetration for diamondoid networks, i.e. the four interpenetrating adamantane units are not all equally spaced, nor positioned exactly along one single line, thereby leading to open intersecting channels within the interwoven nets [15]. Note that a Co-derivative reported by Kwon and co-workers [28] and a Zn-derivative reported by Chen et al. [25] with the same organic compositions (2,6-ndc and bpe) show different structures that are 3D triply and doubly interpenetrated networks with an α-polonium-related (cubic) topology, respectively, on the basis of paddle-wheel dinuclear secondary building units (SBUs). As reported in the literature, the construction of functional coordination polymers based on diamondoid structures is of particular interest, because of the general robustness and nonlinear optical properties of three-dimensionally interconnected diamondoid networks [11, 15, 18, 20].

A comparable reaction mixture and similar reaction conditions as for 1, except the use of 4,4′-bpy instead of bpe results in the formation of a markedly different structure, [Ni2(2,6-ndc)2(4,4′-bpy)]n (2, Scheme 1). By adopting the same conditions, a Co-derivative, [Co2(2,6-ndc)2(4,4′-bpy)]n (3), was obtained.

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies revealed that compounds 2 and 3 are isomorphous and isostructural. The coordination parameters around the metal centers for 2 and 3 are listed in Tables III and IV, respectively, and an ORTEP drawing is shown in Fig. 3. The crystal structures of 2 and 3 are constructed from the paddle-wheel dinuclear [M2(O2C)4] (M = Ni (2), Co (3)) SBUs, in which the two metal centers are held together by four 2,6-ndc linkers with bis(syn,syn-bridging bidentate) bonding modes (Ni–O = 1.986(6)–2.030(7) Å for 2; Co–O = 2.000(8)–2.073(8) Å for 3). The SBUs are interconnected to a 2D grid-like (4,4) layer network, as depicted in Fig. 4, pillared by 4,4′-bpy ligands with M–N bond lengths of 2.003(6)–2.032(6) Å and 2.055(10)–2.090(9) Å for 2 and 3, respectively. Thus, the dinuclear SBUs can be topologically considered to be six-connected octahedral nodes, as shown in Fig. 3, to form an extended neutral 3D elongated primitive cubic framework (Fig. 5a). The 3D net thus possesses a large cubic cavity with mesh dimensions of approximately 13.1 × 13.1 × 13.7 Å. Several metal-organic frameworks of cuboidal nets such as [Zn2(2,6-ndc)2(bpe)]·5DMF·H2O (DMF = N,N-dimethylformamide) [25], [Zn2(BDC)2(4,4′-bpy)]·G (G = 2DMF·H2O or none; BDC = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate) [24], and [Co2(2,6-ndc)2(bpe)]·G (G = 2/3H2O or C6H6·H2O) [28] constructed from mixed-ligand systems of different dicarboxylates and organic pillars have been recently published. They exhibit doubly and triply interpenetrating networks but have free volumes accomplished by lattice solvent molecules. The doubly interpenetrating net [Zn2(BDC)2(4,4′-bpy)] even serves as a rare example of a reversible open-dense phase transformation in the crystalline state upon guest inclusion and exclusion, which can be attributed to the rigid and flexible nature of 4,4′-bpy linkers and the variable distortion of the paddle-wheel clusters [24]. Compounds 2 and 3, however, have three identical interpenetrating nets with an α-polonium-related topology, giving a highly dense, packed phase and without an extremely large void space (Fig. 5b).

Results of TG analyses of compounds 1 and 2 are shown in Fig. 6. For 1, a weight loss of 3.9% occurred over the temperature range from 127 to 145 °C, which corresponds to the removal of a coordinated water molecule per formula unit (calcd. 3.8%). The water-free material is then thermally stable at temperatures up to 304 °C, followed by a two-step decomposition process to give the final residual NiO (found 15.9%; calcd. 15.8%). In the case of 2, the TG curve showed that the thermal decomposition of the stable framework began at a temperature of 332 °C and ended at a temperature of 528 °C, resulting in residual NiO (found 22.7%; calcd. 22.2%).

Conclusions

In the present work, we successfully demonstrate the self-recognition of 3D porous frameworks in the formation of a fourfold interpenetrating diamondoid net and a threefold interpenetrating cuboidal net. The products are densely packed and exhibit a high thermal stability (decomposing under N2 at T > 300 °C). Although many factors are able to influence the number of interpenetrating nets, the adjustment in the degree of interpenetration can be achieved here by varying only the organic pillar motifs.

Acknowledgments

We thank Academia Sinica and the National Science Council of Taiwan for financial support. We also express our gratitude to Mr. Ting-Shen Kuo, National Taiwan Normal University for assistance with the X-ray structure analysis.

(%): C: 58.18, H: 2.87, N: 3.99; Found: C: 57.96, H: 2.84, N: 3.99.Synthesis of [Co2(2,6-ndc)2(4,4'-bpy)]n(3)Brown crystals of 3 were obtained by adopting the same procedures as 1, while Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O and 4,4'-bpy were used instead of Ni(NO3)2⋅6H2O and trans-1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethylene. Yield: 59%. Elemental analysis for CoC17H10NO4, Calcd. (%): C: 58.14, H: 2.87, N: 3.99; Found: C: 57.95, H: 2.72, N: 4.07.X-ray CrystallographySuitable single crystals of 1-3 were selected for indexing and the collection of intensity data. Measurements were performed using graphite-monochromatized Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) on a Nonius Kappa CCD. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares method on F2 using the SHELX-97 [29] program packages. Anisotropical thermal factors were assigned to non-hydrogen atoms. The C-H hydrogen atoms were assigned by geometrical calculation and refined as a riding model while the O-H hydrogen atoms were located from the difference Fourier maps. Basic information pertaining to the crystal parameters and structure refinements for 1-3 are summarized in Table I. CCDC-618016 (1), CCDC-618017 (2), and CCDC-618018 (3) contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge at http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/conts/retrieving.htm [or from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB21EZ, UK; fax: (+44) 1223-336-033; or e-mail: deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk] Results and DiscussionHydrothermal reactions of 2,6-H2ndc and bpe with Ni(NO3)2⋅6H2O under alkaline (NaOH) conditions successfully afforded greenish crystals (Scheme 1), which were characterized as [Ni(2,6-ndc)(bpe)(H2O)]n (1) by elemental analysis and single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies. As shown in Fig. 1, the nickel center in 1 is present in a distorted octahedral geometry of N2O4 donor sets, arising from two distinct bpe ligands in a cis configuration (Ni1-N1 = 2.078(4) Å, Ni1-N2 = 2.082(4) Å, N1-Ni1-N2, 87.95(14)°, Table II), one monodentate and one chelated carboxylate group from two 2,6-ndc ligands (Ni1-O = 2.029(3)-2.168(3) Å), and one water molecule (Ni1-O1 = 2.074(3) Å). Both of the two crystallographically independent 2,6-ndc ligands are bridged to two NiII ions, but their bonding characteristics are different, viz bis(monodentate) and bis(chelating bidentate) modes. The coordinated water molecule (O1) is intramolecularly hydrogen bonded (H⋅⋅⋅O, 1.82 Å; O⋅⋅⋅O, 2.58 Å; OH⋅⋅⋅O, 133°) to the non-coordinated nearby oxygen (O3) of the monodentate carboxylate group of the 2,6-ndc ligand. This hydrogen bonding interaction plays an important role in stabilizing the structure. Interestingly, the six-coordinated NiII center acts as a pseudo-tetrahedral four-connected node, which connects to four other NiII centers through two anionic 2,6-ndc and two neutral bpe ligands, resulting in the formation of a diamondoid network (Fig. 2). The Ni⋅⋅⋅Ni separations in the adamantoid cage unit along Ni⋅⋅⋅2,6-ndc⋅⋅⋅Ni are 12.88 and 13.59 Å, while, for Ni⋅⋅⋅bpe⋅⋅⋅Ni, the values are 13.53 and 13.54 Å. The large void space generated is filled by the appearance of a fourfold diamondoid structure, in which four independent equivalent nets are interpenetrated in the aligned normal type with an equally inter-net space of 7.599 Å, along the a axis (the shortest one) of the unit cell, thus, leading to an overall dense phase. The interpenetrating 3D diamondoid net of 1 is further stabilized through noncovalent inter-net OH⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds (H⋅⋅⋅O, 2.10 Å; O⋅⋅⋅O, 2.76 Å; OH⋅⋅⋅O5, 125°) between the coordinated water molecule (O1) and one of the chelated carboxylate oxygen (O5) atom of 2,6-ndc ligand in neighboring net. This provides a good case for comparison with a fourfold interpenetrating diamondoid net, Cd(imidazole-4-acrylate)2, which presents spring-like NH⋅⋅⋅O net-to-net hydrogen-bonding interactions and causes an abnormal type of interpenetration for diamondoid networks, i.e. the four interpenetrating adamantane units are not all equally spaced, nor positioned exactly along one single line, thereby leading to open intersecting channels within the interwoven nets [15]. Note that a Co-derivative reported by Kwon and co-workers [28] and a Zn-derivative reported by Chen et al. [25] with the same organic compositions (2,6-ndc and bpe) show different structures that are 3D triply and doubly interpenetrated networks with an α-polonium-related (cubic) topology, respectively, on the basis of paddle-wheel dinuclear secondary building units (SBUs). As reported in the literature, the construction of functional coordination polymers based on diamondoid structures is of particular interest, because of the general robustness and nonlinear optical properties of three-dimensionally interconnected diamondoid networks [11, 15, 18, 20]. A comparable reaction mixture and similar reaction conditions as for 1, except the use of 4,4'-bpy instead of bpe results in the formation of a markedly different structure, [Ni2(2,6-ndc)2(4,4'-bpy)]n (2, Scheme 1). By adopting the same conditions, a Co-derivative, [Co2(2,6-ndc)2(4,4'-bpy)]n (3), was obtained.Single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies revealed that compounds 2 and 3 are isomorphous and isostructural. The coordination parameters around the metal centers for 2 and 3 are listed in Tables III and IV, respectively, and an ORTEP drawing is shown in Fig. 3. The crystal structures of 2 and 3 are constructed from the paddle-wheel dinuclear [M2(O2C)4] (M = Ni (2), Co (3)) SBUs, in which the two metal centers are held together by four 2,6-ndc linkers with bis(syn,syn-bridging bidentate) bonding modes (Ni-O = 1.986(6)-2.030(7) Å for 2; Co-O = 2.000(8)-2.073(8) Å for 3). The SBUs are interconnected to a 2D grid-like (4,4) layer network, as depicted in Fig. 4, pillared by 4,4'-bpy ligands with M-N bond lengths of 2.003(6)-2.032(6) Å and 2.055(10)-2.090(9) Å for 2 and 3, respectively. Thus, the dinuclear SBUs can be topologically considered to be six-connected octahedral nodes, as shown in Fig. 3, to form an extended neutral 3D elongated primitive cubic framework (Fig. 5a). The 3D net thus possesses a large cubic cavity with mesh dimensions of approximately 13.1 × 13.1 × 13.7 Å. Several metal-organic frameworks of cuboidal nets such as [Zn2(2,6-ndc)2(bpe)]⋅5DMF⋅H2O (DMF = N,N-dimethylformamide) [25], [Zn2(BDC)2(4,4'-bpy)]⋅G (G = 2DMF⋅H2O or none; BDC = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate) [24], and [Co2(2,6-ndc)2(bpe)]⋅G (G = 2/3H2O or C6H6⋅H2O) [28] constructed from mixed-ligand systems of different dicarboxylates and organic pillars have been recently published. They exhibit doubly and triply interpenetrating networks but have free volumes accomplished by lattice solvent molecules. The doubly interpenetrating net [Zn2(BDC)2(4,4'-bpy)] even serves as a rare example of a reversible open-dense phase transformation in the crystalline state upon guest inclusion and exclusion, which can be attributed to the rigid and flexible nature of 4,4'-bpy linkers and the variable distortion of the paddle-wheel clusters [24]. Compounds 2 and 3, however, have three identical interpenetrating nets with an α-polonium-related topology, giving a highly dense, packed phase and without an extremely large void space (Fig. 5b). Results of TG analyses of compounds 1 and 2 are shown in Fig. 6. For 1, a weight loss of 3.9% occurred over the temperature range from 127 to 145 °C, which corresponds to the removal of a coordinated water molecule per formula unit (calcd. 3.8%). The water-free material is then thermally stable at temperatures up to 304 °C, followed by a two-step decomposition process to give the final residual NiO (found 15.9%; calcd. 15.8%). In the case of 2, the TG curve showed that the thermal decomposition of the stable framework began at a temperature of 332 °C and ended at a temperature of 528 °C, resulting in residual NiO (found 22.7%; calcd. 22.2%).ConclusionsIn the present work, we successfully demonstrate the self-recognition of 3D porous frameworks in the formation of a fourfold interpenetrating diamondoid net and a threefold interpenetrating cuboidal net. The products are densely packed and exhibit a high thermal stability (decomposing under N2 at T > 300 °C). Although many factors are able to influence the number of interpenetrating nets, the adjustment in the degree of interpenetration can be achieved here by varying only the organic pillar motifs. elements.content: Compound [Ni(2,6-ndc)(bpe)(H2O)]n (1) was prepared by the hydrothermal reaction of 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (2,6-H2ndc) and trans-1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethylene (bpe) with Ni(NO3)2·6H2O under alkaline (NaOH) conditions. Treatment of 2,6-H2ndc, 4,4′-bipyridine (4,4′-bpy) with M(NO3)2·6H2O (M = Ni or Co) under similar conditions afforded compounds [Ni2(2,6-ndc)2(4,4′-bpy)]n (2) and [Co2(2,6-ndc)2(4,4′-bpy)]n (3), respectively. A single-crystal X-ray diffraction study revealed that compound 1 adopts a 3D fourfold interpenetrating diamondoid network stabilized by inter-net OH···O hydrogen bonds. The anionic 2,6-ndc ligand presents two different bonding characteristics, bis(monodentate) and bis(chelating bidentate) modes. A solid-state structural analysis revealed that compounds 2 and 3 are isomorphous and isostructural. Both present a 3D threefold interpenetrating cuboidal framework, consisting of a 2D (4,4)-net of interconnected [M2(O2C)4] (M = Ni, Co) paddle-wheel dinuclear units, and pillared by 4,4′-bpy ligands. The degree of interpenetration of these compounds could be adjusted successfully by varying only the organic pillar motifs.

elements.content: The fabrication of metal-directed inorganic–organic hybrid open frameworks through crystal engineering is of great interest partly because of their potential applications as functional materials [1–5]. Among the several types of net-assembled polymeric frameworks reported so far, ordered, periodic entanglement interpenetrating nets are often encountered. In comparison with encapsulation to “hetero-recognition”, the decorated interpenetrating networks may be apt to have “self-recognition” [6] characteristics, to avoid the formation of large open channels or cavities, thus presenting a unique class of model compounds for studies dealing with the modification of their robustness, degree of interpenetration, and porosity [5, 7–28]. Interpenetration is thought to have a negative impact on the size and accessibility of pores in microporous materials. Although it is most likely strongly related to the length of the spacer ligands, factors that control the degree of interpenetration during the self-assembly process remain largely unknown and/or unproven [9, 10]. We recently have successfully demonstrated a feasible way for obtaining accessible free volume and permanent porosity in a thermally stable, fourfold interpenetrating diamondoid net, Cd(imidazole-4-acrylate)2, by employing strong net-to-net hydrogen bonding interactions [15]. Herein we report on controlling the diversity of the structural topologies in porous polymeric networks. The self-recognition of 3D porous frameworks, leading to the formation of either a fourfold interpenetrating diamondoid net or a threefold interpenetrating cuboidal net, can be tuned by varying only the organic pillar spacer under hydrothermal conditions.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The fabrication of metal-directed inorganic-organic hybrid open frameworks through crystal engineering is of great interest partly because of their potential applications as functional materials [1-5]. Among the several types of net-assembled polymeric frameworks reported so far, ordered, periodic entanglement interpenetrating nets are often encountered. In comparison with encapsulation to "hetero-recognition", the decorated interpenetrating networks may be apt to have "self-recognition" [6] characteristics, to avoid the formation of large open channels or cavities, thus presenting a unique class of model compounds for studies dealing with the modification of their robustness, degree of interpenetration, and porosity [5, 7-28]. Interpenetration is thought to have a negative impact on the size and accessibility of pores in microporous materials. Although it is most likely strongly related to the length of the spacer ligands, factors that control the degree of interpenetration during the self-assembly process remain largely unknown and/or unproven [9, 10]. We recently have successfully demonstrated a feasible way for obtaining accessible free volume and permanent porosity in a thermally stable, fourfold interpenetrating diamondoid net, Cd(imidazole-4-acrylate)2, by employing strong net-to-net hydrogen bonding interactions [15]. Herein we report on controlling the diversity of the structural topologies in porous polymeric networks. The self-recognition of 3D porous frameworks, leading to the formation of either a fourfold interpenetrating diamondoid net or a threefold interpenetrating cuboidal net, can be tuned by varying only the organic pillar spacer under hydrothermal conditions.

Experimental

General Remarks

All reagents were purchased from commercial sources and were used as received without further purification. Elemental analyses were conducted on a Perkin-Elmer 2400 CHN elemental analyzer. Thermogravimetric (TG) analyses were performed under flowing nitrogen on a Perkin-Elmer TGA-7 analyzer at a heating rate of 3 °C/min for all measurements.

elements.content: A mixture of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (0.30 mmol), 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (2,6-H2ndc, 0.10 mmol), trans-1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethylene (bpe, 0.10 mmol), and NaOH (0.65 M, 0.3 mL) in an aqueous solution (3 mL) was conducted in an acid digestion bomb, which was heated at 160 °C for 72 h, and then slowly cooled to room temperature at a rate 3.3 °C per hour. Greenish crystals of [Ni(2,6-ndc)(bpe)(H2O)]n(1) were obtained and collected in 28% yield by filtration and washed with ethanol, and then dried at room temperature. Elemental analysis for NiC24H18N2O5, Calcd. (%): C: 60.93, H: 3.83, N: 5.92; Found: C: 61.30, H: 3.65, N: 5.40.

Hydrothermal reactions of 2,6-H2ndc and bpe with Ni(NO3)2·6H2O under alkaline (NaOH) conditions successfully afforded greenish crystals (Scheme 1), which were characterized as [Ni(2,6-ndc)(bpe)(H2O)]n (1) by elemental analysis and single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies. As shown in Fig. 1, the nickel center in 1 is present in a distorted octahedral geometry of N2O4 donor sets, arising from two distinct bpe ligands in a cis configuration (Ni1–N1 = 2.078(4) Å, Ni1–N2 = 2.082(4) Å, N1–Ni1–N2, 87.95(14)°, Table II), one monodentate and one chelated carboxylate group from two 2,6-ndc ligands (Ni1–O = 2.029(3)–2.168(3) Å), and one water molecule (Ni1–O1 = 2.074(3) Å). Both of the two crystallographically independent 2,6-ndc ligands are bridged to two NiII ions, but their bonding characteristics are different, viz bis(monodentate) and bis(chelating bidentate) modes. The coordinated water molecule (O1) is intramolecularly hydrogen bonded (H···O, 1.82 Å; O···O, 2.58 Å; OH···O, 133°) to the non-coordinated nearby oxygen (O3) of the monodentate carboxylate group of the 2,6-ndc ligand. This hydrogen bonding interaction plays an important role in stabilizing the structure.

Results and Discussion

Hydrothermal reactions of 2,6-H2ndc and bpe with Ni(NO3)2⋅6H2O under alkaline (NaOH) conditions successfully afforded greenish crystals (Scheme 1), which were characterized as [Ni(2,6-ndc)(bpe)(H2O)]n (1) by elemental analysis and single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies. As shown in Fig. 1, the nickel center in 1 is present in a distorted octahedral geometry of N2O4 donor sets, arising from two distinct bpe ligands in a cis configuration (Ni1-N1 = 2.078(4) Å, Ni1-N2 = 2.082(4) Å, N1-Ni1-N2, 87.95(14)°, Table II), one monodentate and one chelated carboxylate group from two 2,6-ndc ligands (Ni1-O = 2.029(3)-2.168(3) Å), and one water molecule (Ni1-O1 = 2.074(3) Å). Both of the two crystallographically independent 2,6-ndc ligands are bridged to two NiII ions, but their bonding characteristics are different, viz bis(monodentate) and bis(chelating bidentate) modes. The coordinated water molecule (O1) is intramolecularly hydrogen bonded (H⋅⋅⋅O, 1.82 Å; O⋅⋅⋅O, 2.58 Å; OH⋅⋅⋅O, 133°) to the non-coordinated nearby oxygen (O3) of the monodentate carboxylate group of the 2,6-ndc ligand. This hydrogen bonding interaction plays an important role in stabilizing the structure.

Interestingly, the six-coordinated NiII center acts as a pseudo-tetrahedral four-connected node, which connects to four other NiII centers through two anionic 2,6-ndc and two neutral bpe ligands, resulting in the formation of a diamondoid network (Fig. 2). The Ni···Ni separations in the adamantoid cage unit along Ni···2,6-ndc···Ni are 12.88 and 13.59 Å, while, for Ni···bpe···Ni, the values are 13.53 and 13.54 Å. The large void space generated is filled by the appearance of a fourfold diamondoid structure, in which four independent equivalent nets are interpenetrated in the aligned normal type with an equally inter-net space of 7.599 Å, along the a axis (the shortest one) of the unit cell, thus, leading to an overall dense phase. The interpenetrating 3D diamondoid net of 1 is further stabilized through noncovalent inter-net OH···O hydrogen bonds (H···O, 2.10 Å; O···O, 2.76 Å; OH···O5, 125°) between the coordinated water molecule (O1) and one of the chelated carboxylate oxygen (O5) atom of 2,6-ndc ligand in neighboring net. This provides a good case for comparison with a fourfold interpenetrating diamondoid net, Cd(imidazole-4-acrylate)2, which presents spring-like NH···O net-to-net hydrogen-bonding interactions and causes an abnormal type of interpenetration for diamondoid networks, i.e. the four interpenetrating adamantane units are not all equally spaced, nor positioned exactly along one single line, thereby leading to open intersecting channels within the interwoven nets [15]. Note that a Co-derivative reported by Kwon and co-workers [28] and a Zn-derivative reported by Chen et al. [25] with the same organic compositions (2,6-ndc and bpe) show different structures that are 3D triply and doubly interpenetrated networks with an α-polonium-related (cubic) topology, respectively, on the basis of paddle-wheel dinuclear secondary building units (SBUs). As reported in the literature, the construction of functional coordination polymers based on diamondoid structures is of particular interest, because of the general robustness and nonlinear optical properties of three-dimensionally interconnected diamondoid networks [11, 15, 18, 20].

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies revealed that compounds 2 and 3 are isomorphous and isostructural. The coordination parameters around the metal centers for 2 and 3 are listed in Tables III and IV, respectively, and an ORTEP drawing is shown in Fig. 3. The crystal structures of 2 and 3 are constructed from the paddle-wheel dinuclear [M2(O2C)4] (M = Ni (2), Co (3)) SBUs, in which the two metal centers are held together by four 2,6-ndc linkers with bis(syn,syn-bridging bidentate) bonding modes (Ni–O = 1.986(6)–2.030(7) Å for 2; Co–O = 2.000(8)–2.073(8) Å for 3). The SBUs are interconnected to a 2D grid-like (4,4) layer network, as depicted in Fig. 4, pillared by 4,4′-bpy ligands with M–N bond lengths of 2.003(6)–2.032(6) Å and 2.055(10)–2.090(9) Å for 2 and 3, respectively. Thus, the dinuclear SBUs can be topologically considered to be six-connected octahedral nodes, as shown in Fig. 3, to form an extended neutral 3D elongated primitive cubic framework (Fig. 5a). The 3D net thus possesses a large cubic cavity with mesh dimensions of approximately 13.1 × 13.1 × 13.7 Å. Several metal-organic frameworks of cuboidal nets such as [Zn2(2,6-ndc)2(bpe)]·5DMF·H2O (DMF = N,N-dimethylformamide) [25], [Zn2(BDC)2(4,4′-bpy)]·G (G = 2DMF·H2O or none; BDC = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate) [24], and [Co2(2,6-ndc)2(bpe)]·G (G = 2/3H2O or C6H6·H2O) [28] constructed from mixed-ligand systems of different dicarboxylates and organic pillars have been recently published. They exhibit doubly and triply interpenetrating networks but have free volumes accomplished by lattice solvent molecules. The doubly interpenetrating net [Zn2(BDC)2(4,4′-bpy)] even serves as a rare example of a reversible open-dense phase transformation in the crystalline state upon guest inclusion and exclusion, which can be attributed to the rigid and flexible nature of 4,4′-bpy linkers and the variable distortion of the paddle-wheel clusters [24]. Compounds 2 and 3, however, have three identical interpenetrating nets with an α-polonium-related topology, giving a highly dense, packed phase and without an extremely large void space (Fig. 5b).

Compounds 2 and 3, however, have three identical interpenetrating nets with an α-polonium-related topology, giving a highly dense, packed phase and without an extremely large void space (Fig. 5b).

elements.content: Results of TG analyses of compounds 1 and 2 are shown in Fig. 6. For 1, a weight loss of 3.9% occurred over the temperature range from 127 to 145 °C, which corresponds to the removal of a coordinated water molecule per formula unit (calcd. 3.8%). The water-free material is then thermally stable at temperatures up to 304 °C, followed by a two-step decomposition process to give the final residual NiO (found 15.9%; calcd. 15.8%). In the case of 2, the TG curve showed that the thermal decomposition of the stable framework began at a temperature of 332 °C and ended at a temperature of 528 °C, resulting in residual NiO (found 22.7%; calcd. 22.2%).

In the case of 2, the TG curve showed that the thermal decomposition of the stable framework began at a temperature of 332 °C and ended at a temperature of 528 °C, resulting in residual NiO (found 22.7%; calcd. 22.2%).

elements.content: In the present work, we successfully demonstrate the self-recognition of 3D porous frameworks in the formation of a fourfold interpenetrating diamondoid net and a threefold interpenetrating cuboidal net. The products are densely packed and exhibit a high thermal stability (decomposing under N2 at T > 300 °C). Although many factors are able to influence the number of interpenetrating nets, the adjustment in the degree of interpenetration can be achieved here by varying only the organic pillar motifs.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In the present work, we successfully demonstrate the self-recognition of 3D porous frameworks in the formation of a fourfold interpenetrating diamondoid net and a threefold interpenetrating cuboidal net. The products are densely packed and exhibit a high thermal stability (decomposing under N2 at T > 300 °C). Although many factors are able to influence the number of interpenetrating nets, the adjustment in the degree of interpenetration can be achieved here by varying only the organic pillar motifs.

cln_elements.content:
A mixture of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (0.30 mmol), 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (2,6-H2ndc, 0.10 mmol), trans-1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethylene (bpe, 0.10 mmol), and NaOH (0.65 M, 0.3 mL) in an aqueous solution (3 mL) was conducted in an acid digestion bomb, which was heated at 160 °C for 72 h, and then slowly cooled to room temperature at a rate 3.3 °C per hour. Greenish crystals of [Ni(2,6-ndc)(bpe)(H2O)]n(1) were obtained and collected in 28% yield by filtration and washed with ethanol, and then dried at room temperature. Elemental analysis for NiC24H18N2O5, Calcd. (%): C: 60.93, H: 3.83, N: 5.92; Found: C: 61.30, H: 3.65, N: 5.40.

Synthesis of [Ni<sub>2</sub>(2,6-ndc)<sub>2</sub>(4,4′-bpy)]<sub><italic>n</italic></sub>(<bold>2</bold>)

Green crystals of 2 were obtained by adopting the same conditions as 1 but using 4,4′-bipyridine 4,4′-bpy instead of trans-1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethylene. Yield: 95%. Elemental analysis for NiC17H10NO4, Calcd. (%): C: 58.18, H: 2.87, N: 3.99; Found: C: 57.96, H: 2.84, N: 3.99.

Synthesis of [Co<sub>2</sub>(2,6-ndc)<sub>2</sub>(4,4′-bpy)]<sub><italic>n</italic></sub>(<bold>3</bold>)

Brown crystals of 3 were obtained by adopting the same procedures as 1, while Co(NO3)2·6H2O and 4,4′-bpy were used instead of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O and trans-1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethylene. Yield: 59%. Elemental analysis for CoC17H10NO4, Calcd. (%): C: 58.14, H: 2.87, N: 3.99; Found: C: 57.95, H: 2.72, N: 4.07.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [Ni(2,6-ndc)(bpe)(H2O)]n(1)

A mixture of Ni(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.30 mmol), 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (2,6-H2ndc, 0.10 mmol), trans-1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethylene (bpe, 0.10 mmol), and NaOH (0.65 M, 0.3 mL) in an aqueous solution (3 mL) was conducted in an acid digestion bomb, which was heated at 160 °C for 72 h, and then slowly cooled to room temperature at a rate 3.3 °C per hour. Greenish crystals of [Ni(2,6-ndc)(bpe)(H2O)]n(1) were obtained and collected in 28% yield by filtration and washed with ethanol, and then dried at room temperature. Elemental analysis for NiC24H18N2O5, Calcd. (%): C: 60.93, H: 3.83, N: 5.92; Found: C: 61.30, H: 3.65, N: 5.40.

Synthesis of [Ni2(2,6-ndc)2(4,4'-bpy)]n(2)

Green crystals of 2 were obtained by adopting the same conditions as 1 but using 4,4'-bipyridine 4,4'-bpy instead of trans-1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethylene. Yield: 95%. Elemental analysis for NiC17H10NO4, Calcd. (%): C: 58.18, H: 2.87, N: 3.99; Found: C: 57.96, H: 2.84, N: 3.99.

Synthesis of [Co2(2,6-ndc)2(4,4'-bpy)]n(3)

Brown crystals of 3 were obtained by adopting the same procedures as 1, while Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O and 4,4'-bpy were used instead of Ni(NO3)2⋅6H2O and trans-1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethylene. Yield: 59%. Elemental analysis for CoC17H10NO4, Calcd. (%): C: 58.14, H: 2.87, N: 3.99; Found: C: 57.95, H: 2.72, N: 4.07.

cln_elements.content: Results of TG analyses of compounds 1 and 2 are shown in Fig. 6. For 1, a weight loss of 3.9% occurred over the temperature range from 127 to 145 °C, which corresponds to the removal of a coordinated water molecule per formula unit (calcd. 3.8%). The water-free material is then thermally stable at temperatures up to 304 °C, followed by a two-step decomposition process to give the final residual NiO (found 15.9%; calcd. 15.8%). In the case of 2, the TG curve showed that the thermal decomposition of the stable framework began at a temperature of 332 °C and ended at a temperature of 528 °C, resulting in residual NiO (found 22.7%; calcd. 22.2%).
